Data-Driven Transit Solutions

About ClearLane

Learn about our mission to protect student study time through evidence-based bus enforcement strategies.

View Our Research See Findings

Our Mission

To protect the vital study time of CUNY students by using data science to identify and solve bus enforcement failures that disrupt their daily commutes.

üìö

Student-Centered

Every analysis prioritizes the academic success of working students who depend on reliable transit.

üìä

Data-Driven

Evidence-based solutions using comprehensive analysis of 3.7 million violation records.

üîç

Transparent

Open methodology and findings to build trust and enable replication.

‚ö°

Actionable

Ready-to-implement solutions with clear ROI and measurable impact.

The Story Behind ClearLane

ClearLane began with a simple observation: my 2-hour BxM10 commute from the Bronx to Baruch College was my most productive study time. But when buses were delayed by bus lane violations, I lost more than travel time‚ÄîI lost my rolling study hall. This personal experience led to a deeper investigation. Using data science skills developed through my studies, I analyzed 3.7 million MTA violation records to understand the patterns behind these disruptions. The results were clear: enforcement failures are predictable, localized, and disproportionately impact students during their most critical study hours. ClearLane represents the intersection of personal experience, academic rigor, and civic engagement‚Äîturning a daily frustration into actionable insights for better transit policy.

Our Research Approach

Rigorous data science methodology ensures our findings are accurate, reproducible, and actionable.

1

Data Collection

Comprehensive analysis of 3.7M MTA violation records, CUNY campus locations, and bus route data

Multiple data sources including NYC Open Data, MTA GTFS feeds, and CUNY institutional research

2

Spatial Analysis

Geographic clustering using DBSCAN to identify violation hotspots

Haversine distance calculations and buffer zone analysis around CUNY campuses

3

Temporal Analysis

Time-series analysis of violation patterns by hour, day, and academic calendar

Peak violation identification during 7-10 AM student commute hours

4

Predictive Modeling

Machine learning models to predict high-impact enforcement opportunities

Random Forest regression with 85% accuracy in hotspot prediction

5

Impact Assessment

ROI analysis and speed improvement projections for targeted enforcement

12% speed improvement potential with 40% violation reduction

What's Next

ClearLane is ready for implementation and scaling across NYC.

Pilot Program

Deploy targeted enforcement at top 10 CUNY-impacting hotspots

Timeline: 3-6 months

Citywide Rollout

Scale to all 90 identified high-priority locations

Timeline: 6-12 months

Policy Integration

Integrate findings into MTA enforcement strategy

Timeline: Ongoing

Research Expansion

Extend analysis to other student populations and transit modes
